filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 135KB; 42 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 15KB to 441KB.
filedesc.publicationstmt:
Charlottesville: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; IATH
We have observed some optical distortion, including the so-called moir effect, in the display of several images when viewed through either the ImageSizer window or in the Inote Panner. These effects are not present in the non-Java inline displays of the same images, nor in their enlargements, nor in Inote itself. The distortion, we believe, is a product of the geometric compression of the image by the ImageSizer and Panner. We anticipate resolving this issue in the future, but we have elected to publish this edition as is since the integrity of the image data is not at stake—only its representation according to some of the Archive's display mechanisms. Users who wish to verify the accuracy of a given impression are advised to examine either its enlargement or the non-Java inline version of the same image.
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of new electronic editions for two works in Blake's emblem series: For Children: The Gates of Paradise and the revised and augmented version For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise. Through a numbered series of intaglio plates with inscriptions ranging from single words to brief aphorisms, Blake puts the course of human life from birth to death in psychological perspective. Some of the emblems form narrative sequences; others exemplify mental states and their reification in the external world. Blake etched in intaglio the eighteen plates of For Children in 1793 and printed all extant copies (A-E) in the same year. The copy published in the Archive is Copy D, from the Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress.
In about 1820, Blake revised For Children: The Gates of Paradise, giving the work a new title, For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise, reworking the design plates at least twice, and adding three new text plates at the end (19-21). Plates 19-20 contain brief interpretive statements keyed by number to the preceding design plates. The final plate is addressed to Satan as the "God of This [fallen] World." Copies A and B were probably printed c. 1820. Copies C and D, plus a large group of impressions never collated into complete Copies by Blake but now divided into what are designated as Copies J-N, date from c. 1825. Copies E-I are probably posthumous. We now publish Copy D, from the collection of the Pierpont Morgan Library, New York.
Both electronic editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and new images scanned and color-corrected from first-generation 4x5" transparencies; they are each fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
With the publication of these two titles, the Archive now contains 33 copies of 18 separate books, including at least one copy of every one of Blake's works in illuminated printing except the 100 plates of Jerusalem (forthcoming).
Also, we are pleased to announce that a Tour of the Archive is now available online. Through a sequence of several dozen graphical screenshots linked to narrative commentary, the Tour introduces users to the basic organization and structure of the Archive, the features of its interface, its search options, and the function of the Inote and ImageSizer applications. The Tour is located in the "About the Archive" wing of the site. Available as the first link off our main table of contents page at the URL above, the "About the Archive" materials include, in addition to the Tour, a statement of Editorial Principles and Methodology, a Frequently Asked Questions list, a Technical Summary, and an updated version of the article-length Plan of the Archive detailing our intentions with regard to Blake's non-illuminated works--and more. We hope that the Tour, together with these other materials, will prove valuable both to our own growing user community and to scholars interested in the theory and practice of electronic editing more generally.

objtitle.title: *For the Sexes: The Gates of Paradise*

objdescid.origination: William Blakeauthor, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer
Catherine BlakeprinterBlake is recorded only as the publisher in the book, but there can be no question that he designed the images and authored their captions.

imprint.pubplace: London"Lambeth" (a suburb of London) is given as the place of publication on Plates 6, 9, 10, 13, 14, 16, and 17. This refers to the place of publication of For Children: The Gates of Paradise in 1793. Blake lived in London during the revisions to Plates 1-18, the etching and engraving of Plates 19-21, and the printing of this copy.

objdescid.compdate: 1793, c. 1820Plates 1-18 first etched and engraved in 1793, revised c. 1820; Plates 19-21 etched and engraved c. 1820. The work is based on designs Blake drew in his Notebook; some of these sketches may have been executed c. 1790-92.

objinfo.objorder: 1-21 Bentley plate numbers are used unless otherwise stated.
objinfo.objsize: platemarks ranging in size between 10.5 x 7.4 cm. and 6.1 x 4.2 cm.
objinfo.medium: intaglio etching/engravingThe numbers, 17-19, appearing lower right on Objects 19-21 are in pen and ink. These numbers were probably written by Blake.
objinfo.watermark: J Whatman/1825The watermark appears on Plates 3, 8, 16, and 17.
objinfo.pennednumbers: 17-19 lower right on Plates 19-21These numbers were probably written by Blake.
objinfo.binding: contemporary or near-contemporary half brown calf over marbled boards
objinfo.stabholes: originally stabbed through 3 holes, 6.9 cm. from the top and 3.6 cm. apart

provenance.name: Morgan Library and Museum
provenance.note: Probably Frederick Tatham; Thomas Boddington by 1833; sold from Boddington's library, Sotheby's, 4 Nov. 1895, lot 94 (£21 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch acting for William A. White); the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach by 1929; Mrs. Landon K. Thorne no earlier than 1945 (the year of the last Rosenbach catalogue offering the book for sale); given by Thorne to The Pierpont Morgan Library in 1973.

repository.department: Department of Printed Books and Bindings

illustration.illusobjdesc: We see two large leaves, perhaps oak leaves, growing from a branch. The veins on the lower leaf are particularly prominent. The upper leaf bears a large caterpillar which may be eating the edge of the leaf. The lower leaf cradles an infant or at least the head of an infant with closed eyeswhose body suggests both swaddling bands and a chrysalis. There are slight indications of curly hair on the infant's head.

component.illusobjdesc: We see two large leaves, perhaps oak leaves, growing from a branch. The veins on the lower leaf are particularly prominent.
A large caterpillar rests on the edge of, and may be eating, a leaf.

A leaf cradles an infant--or at least the head of an infant with closed eyes--whose body suggests both swaddling bands and a chrysalis. There are slight indications of curly hair on the infant's head.

lg.l: The Suns Light when he unfolds it
Depends on the Organ that beholds it

desc.objtitle: For the Sexes The Gates of Paradise, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state for For the Sexes. The first state lacks the disc (apparently of the sun) and lines of radiance appearing above line 5 of the text ("Paradise").

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures, both probably gowned and with arms extended horizontally, hover below the first line of text. Their directional orientation is uncertain; we may be seeing them from behind. Below the figure on the left in this pair are three very small hovering figures. The right-most figure in this group appear to have her or his arms raised at 135 degrees. The central figure may have one arm raised at 45 degrees. The companion group on the right includes three (gowned?) and hovering figures, with the head of a fourth figure just visible above and to the left of the central figure in this group. The left-most figure has one arm raised horizontally and the other vertically. Below "Gates" (line 3) in the title, and on each side of the word "of" (line 4), are two hovering angels with large wings. Both have their arms bent with their hands together in an attitude of prayer. The angel on the left faces right; the angel on the right faces left. There are slight indications of a gown worn by the angel on the left. They may be looking down at a portion of the circumference of sun arcing between "of" and "Paradise" (line 5) in the title. Lines of radiance emanate from the arc, suggesting a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A portion of the circumference of sun arcing between "of" and "Paradise" (line 5) in the title. Lines of radiance emanate from the arc, suggesting a sunrise or sunset.

A figure with arms raised horizontally hovers below "For" in the first line of the title inscription (line 1). The figure may be gowned. The figure's directional orientation is uncertain; we may be seeing him or her from behind.

A figure with arms raised horizontally hovers below "Sexes" in the first line of the title inscription (line 1). The figure may be gowned. The figure's directional orientation is uncertain; we may be seeing him or her from behind.
A group of three small figures hovers left of "The" in the second line of text. The right-most figure may have her or his arms raised at 135 degrees.

A group of three small (gowned?) figures hovers right of "The" in the second line of text. There may be the head of a fourth figure above and to the left of the center figure in the group. The left-most figure in the group has one arm raised horizontally and the other vertically.
A gowned angel with large wings hovers, facing right, left of "of" in the title inscription (line 4). The angel's arms are bent with hands raised together in an attitude of prayer.
An angel with large wings hovers, facing left, right of "of" in the title inscription (line 4). The angel's arms are bent with hands raised together in an attitude of prayer.

lg.l: Such are the Gates of Paradise
Who walkd among the Stones of Fire
Then Wept! then rose in Zeal & Awe
And the Dead Corpse from Sinais heat
O Christians Christians! tell me Why
You rear it on your Altars high

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large tree grows up the left margin, with branches arching toward the left in the top third of the image. Its long, dangling branches and/or leaves suggest it may be a willow. A few small plants with large leaves cover the ground below the trunk. To the right, below the tree's largest branch, is a gowned woman striding to the left with legs spread apart. Her hair is drawn into a bun on the back of her head. Her left arm is bent at the elbow and she holds in her left hand two small children or infants. We see only one child's head and the right eye and cheek of the other; a part of the woman's gown, or a separate blanket, covers the children's bodies. The woman, perhaps the children's mother or a nurse, leans over and faces down. She reaches down with her right arm and hand and appears to be pulling a third child or infant out of the earth. We see this child only from the chest up; his or her hair stands on end. The position of the child suggests that it is the anthropomorphic form of a vegetableperhaps a mandrake, traditionally thought to be shaped like a human body. Perhaps the woman has "harvested" the other two children, held in her left arm, in a similar fashion. Plants or trees fill the middle distance right of the woman; trees and a low hill fill the middle distance left of the woman. A few clouds fill the sky behind the tree's limbs and leaves.

component.illusobjdesc: Plants or trees fill the middle distance right of the woman; trees and a low hill fill the middle distance left of the woman.
A large tree grows up the left margin, with branches arching toward the left in the top third of the image. Its long, dangling branches and/or leaves suggest it may be a willow.
A few small plants with large leaves cover the ground below the trunk of the tree.
A few clouds fill the sky behind the tree's limbs and leaves.

A gowned woman strides to the left with legs spread apart. Her hair is drawn into a bun on the back of her head. Her left arm is bent at the elbow and she holds in her left hand two small children or infants. The woman, perhaps the children's mother or a nurse, leans over and faces down. She reaches down with her right arm and hand and appears to be pulling a third child or infant out of the earth. The fingers of her right hand are spread over the child's forehead.

The woman holds two small children or infants in her left arm and hand. We see only the head of one child, facing forward; the second child, above and two the right of the more prominent one, is indicated only by the left eye and cheek, facing up. The bodies of both children are covered with a portion of the woman's gown or a separate blanket.

The woman reaches down with her right arm and hand and appears to be pulling a child or infant out of the earth. We see this child only from the chest up; his or her hair stands on end. The position of the child suggests that it is the anthropomorphic form of a plant--perhaps a mandrake, traditionally thought to be shaped like a human body. Perhaps the woman has "harvested" the other two children, held in her left arm, in a similar fashion.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male, apparently with long hair, sits on the bank of a river or lake with legs crossed at the ankles. He faces down, with eyes closed or partly closed. His arms reach down with his hands resting on his knees; his palms are open and facing down with fingers spread. The lines on his face and his general expression suggest despair or melancholy. To the right is a tree, the barren branches of which arch over the figure. There are several large roots beneath its trunk. Other lines, almost vertical but slightly angled from right to left, cover most of the image and very probably represent rain. A river or lake appears lower left and below the man's feet. As the caption indicates, "Water" (line 1) is the subject, both literal and metaphoric, of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male, apparently with long hair, sits on the bank of a river or lake with legs crossed at the ankles. He faces down, with eyes closed or partly closed. His arms reach down with his hands resting on his knees; his palms are open and facing down with fingers spread. His mouth is slightly open. The lines on his face and his general expression suggest despair or melancholy. He may be a personification of water as both a substance and a psychological state within a Blakean version of humoral theory.
A leafless tree grows up the right margin of the design, with a prominent limb arching over the seated man. There are several large roots on the bank beneath the tree.

The man sits on a bank of earth above a river or lake. This body of water would seem to extend around the left end of the bank, thus making it a diminutive peninsula. Lines, almost vertical but angling slightly to the lower left, indicate heavy rain.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones. He is bearded; his hair is slightly curly. He squats or crouches, with legs spread apart. His left leg is bent sharply at the knee and the right, slightly bent, is extended toward the lower margin of the image. He faces forward, with his arms raised, elbows bent. His hands are above his head; he may be grasping the top of his head with his left hand. The general expression is one of conflict, grief, and pain. He may be a personification of "Earth" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

component.illusobjdesc: A man struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones.

A nude male struggles within a cleft or cavern formed by dark and massive stones. He is bearded; his hair is slightly curly. He squats or crouches, with legs spread apart. His left leg is bent sharply at the knee and the right, slightly bent, is extended toward the lower margin of the image. He faces forward, with his arms raised, elbows bent. His hands are above his head; he may be grasping the top of his head with his left hand. The general expression is one of conflict, grief, and pain. He may be a personification of "Earth" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A youthful, nude male sits, in a crouch-like posture, on a cloud. Parts of this cloud, or perhaps other clouds, extend behind him and in front of him, covering his feet. Fourteen stars fill the night sky. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His hair is curly. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. His chin rests on his right knee. He faces forward, with a lined visage suggesting despair or melancholy. Given the caption, he may be a personification of "air" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

component.illusobjdesc: Clouds and fourteen stars fill the night sky.

A youthful, nude male sits, in a crouch-like posture, on a cloud. His legs are bent sharply at his prominent knees. His hair is curly. His arms are bent at the elbows and extended upward, with both hands clasped over, and perhaps clutching, his forehead. His chin rests on his right knee. He faces forward, with a lined visage suggesting despair or melancholy. Given the caption, he may be a personification of "air" (line 1) within a Blakean version of humoral theory.

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state for For the Sexes. The first state contains only slight indications of scales on the figure's lower stomach and genitals.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young and muscular nude male, with curly (almost snake-like) hair, stands facing forward. Two rounded forms in his hair hint at horns. His legs are spread apart and his arms raised at approximately 135 degrees. His right arm is slightly bent. He holds a spear in his right hand; a large shield is buckled to his left arm and hand. Scales cover his lower stomach and genitals. His mouth is slightly open and his eyes are closed or almost closed. Flames fill the background of the design and rise over the figure's right lower leg. There are also scales among the flames on each side and above the figure. The figure and his setting suggest both Blake's Orc (frequently associated with fire) and Milton's Satan in hell. The caption indicates that he is, at the very least, a personification of "Fire" (line 1).

component.illusobjdesc: Flames fill the background and foreground of the design. There are scales in the fires on both sides and above the figure. There may be smoke on each side of the figure's head. The fire and the character of the figure suggest this may be a vision of hell.

A young and muscular nude male, with curly (almost snake-like) hair, stands facing forward. His eyes appear to be closed. Two curved forms in his hair hint at horns. His legs are spread apart and his arms raised at approximately 135 degrees. His lower stomach and genitals are covered with scales. His right arm is slightly bent. He holds a spear in his right hand; a large shield is buckled to his left arm and hand. His mouth is slightly open and his eyes are closed or almost closed. The figure and his fiery setting suggest both Blake's Orc (frequently associated with fire) and Milton's Satan in hell. The caption indicates that he is, at the very least, a personification of "Fire" (line 1).

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state for For the Sexes. In the first state, there are only two broken pieces of egg in the lower foreground; the piece farthest to the right was added here in the second state.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An infant or young child, nude and probably male, emerges like a hatchling from a broken egg. Given his wings, he may be a putto, cherub, or angel. His legs are crossed at the ankles; his left arm is bent, with his left hand placed on the shell as though he were pushing against it to rise. He faces forward, with his head up and eyes raised. His hair is curly. Clouds fill the sky behind the figure and the egg; three broken pieces of the latter rest in the foreground.

component.illusobjdesc: A child emerges from a broken egg, three pieces of which lie in the foreground. Clouds fill the sky.

An infant or young child, nude and probably male, emerges like a hatchling from a broken egg. Given his wings, he may be a putto, cherub, or angel. His legs are crossed at the ankles; his left arm is bent, with his left hand placed on the shell as though he were pushing against it to rise. He faces forward, with his head up and eyes raised. His hair is curly.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young male strides, with legs spread, from left to right. He wears tights or a combination of breeches and a shirt. His hair is curly. He faces to the right, with a look of surprise or excitement on his face. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is raised vertically but slightly bent at the elbow. He holds a hat in his raised right hand. To the right of his face is a (nude and male?) human figure, perhaps an infant or child, hovering (flying?) in mid-air. We see this figure, also with curly hair, from the back, but facing to the left (toward the large figure). His legs are spread, as though fleeing from the youth with a hat, who may be pursuing him. The hovering figure has his arms extended horizontally. Below, on the ground in the lower right corner of the design, is a second diminutive figure of uncertain gender. He or she may be dead and lies face-down, with the right leg extended and arms extended horizontally in a cruciform position. His or her hair is long. Given the positioning of these two small figures and the iconographic tradition from which this design may have been developed, the two small human forms may be personifications of birds or butterflies; the inscription below the image suggests a more specific identification within the context of Blake's own mythic creations. The middle distance is dominated by leafy plants or trees. Clouds fill the sky in the upper portions of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Clouds fill the sky in the upper portions of the design.
Leafy plants or trees fill the middle distance of the design.

A young male strides, with legs spread, from left to right. He wears tights--or a combination of breeches and a shirt. He may also wear shoes. His hair is curly. He faces to the right, with a look of surprise or excitement on his face. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is raised vertically but slightly bent at the elbow. He holds a hat in his raised right hand. He may be pursuing, and attempting to kill or capture, the flying figure to the right.

To the right of the large figure's face is a (nude and male?) human figure, perhaps an infant or child, hovering (flying?) in mid-air. We see this figure with curly hair from the back, but facing to the left (toward the large figure). His legs are spread, as though fleeing from the youth with a hat, who may be pursuing him. The hovering figure has his arms extended horizontally. Given the iconographic tradition from which this design may have been developed, this figure may be the anthropomorphic form of a bird or butterfly.

A diminutive figure of uncertain gender lies on the ground, lower right. He or she may be dead and lies face-down, with the right leg extended and arms extended horizontally in a cruciform position. His or her hair is long. Given the positioning of the two small figures and the iconographic tradition from which this design may have been developed, the two small human forms may be personifications of birds or butterflies.

lg.l: 7What are these? Alas! the Female Martyr
Is She also the Divine Image

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the left, a youthful male with curly hair strides to the left. Although basically pictured as a nude, a small piece of drapery seems to extend over his buttocks and to the right of his left thigh. His body is twisted and he faces to the right, toward a bearded man. The youth's right arm is raised horizontally and he may be pointing toward this older man. His left arm is raised vertically; he grasps a spear or dart in his raised left hand. He may be about to throw his weapon at the old man. To the right sits an old man with long hair and a long beard. He may be wearing tights or armor. His left leg is bent at the knee, his right extended to the left. His left arm is bent at the elbow and he props his head on his left hand in a posture traditionally indicative of melancholy. His body is twisted and he looks down and to the right. His right arm is raised horizontally and he grasps a large sword in his right hand. The positioning of the two figures and their relative ages suggest that the youth is an Orc- like figure and the old man is his father, as well as a king or Urizen figure. The caption, if spoken by the old man, indicates that the youth is his child. The old man's chair (a primitive throne?) is constructed of large stones. The back of the chair is also constructed of stones. Alternatively, if the perspective is distorted, this may be a ruined wall and the "chair" part of the wall or building. A large tree with several leafy branches arches above the old man. We see a low hill, a mountain behind and to the right, and clouds in the sky on the left. The earth in the foreground may be covered with grass.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful male with curly hair strides to the left. Although basically pictured as a nude, a small piece of drapery seems to extend over his buttocks and to the right of his left thigh. His body is twisted and he faces to the right, toward an old, bearded man. The youth's right arm is raised horizontally and he may be pointing toward the bearded man. His left arm is raised vertically; he grasps a spear or dart in his raised left hand. He may be about to throw his weapon at the old man. The relative positions and ages of the figures suggest that the youth is an Orc figure. If the caption is spoken by the old man, then the youth is his child.

To the right of the young man sits an old man with long hair and a long beard. He may be wearing tights or armor. His left leg is bent at the knee, his right extended to the left. His left arm is bent at the elbow and he props his head on his left hand--a posture traditionally indicative of melancholy. His body is twisted and he looks down and to the right. His right arm is raised horizontally and he grasps a large sword in his right hand. The positioning of the two figures and their relative ages suggest that the youth is an Orc-like figure and the old man is his father, as well as a king or Urizen figure.
The earth in the foreground of the design may be covered with grass.
A large tree with several leafy branches arches through the upper part of the design.

The bearded old man sits on a chair composed of large cut stones. The high back of the chair is also stony. Alternatively, if the perspective is distorted, this may be a ruined wall and the man's "chair" simply more stones from the wall or building.
A low hill fills the middle distance, with a mountain behind and to the right. Clouds fill the sky above.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by the night sky, complete with seven stars and a thin, crescent moon. A long ladder reaches from the surface of the earth, lower right, to the moon. A small figure has just begun to climb the ladder, with the left leg bent at the knee so as to place the left foot on the third rung of the ladder, and the right foot still on the earth. This figure's arms are raised horizontally, with his hands apparently holding the vertical sides of the ladder. The figure is probably male; he wears a hat and may be looking to the right. In the far right corner is a group of two figures, probably a woman on the left (wearing a dress or skirt) and a man on the right. The man has at least his left arm raised horizontally; he may be embracing the woman around her waist. The woman's right arm is bent at the elbow, with her forearm raised horizontally. Both these figures appear to be facing to the left and looking at the man climbing the ladder; the woman may be pointing at him.

component.illusobjdesc: The night sky shows seven stars. A ladder extends from the earth, lower right, to a crescent moon, top left.
A crescent moon appears in the night sky, top left.

A small figure has just begun to climb the ladder, with the left leg bent at the knee so as to place the left foot on the third rung of the ladder, and the right foot still on the earth. This figure's arms are raised horizontally, with his hands apparently holding the vertical sides of the ladder. The figure is probably male; he wears a hat and may be looking to the right.

In the far right corner of the image is a group of two figures, probably a woman on the left (wearing a dress or skirt) and a man on the right. The man has at least his left arm raised horizontally; he may be embracing the woman around her waist. The woman's right arm is bent at the elbow, with her forearm raised horizontally. Both these figures appear to be facing to the left and looking at the man climbing the ladder; the woman may be pointing at him.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by a stormy sky and sea, the former filled with clouds and the latter fraught with two large waves. Near one wave crest we see a human arm raised vertically, fingers spread apart. This figure's head (just to the left of the arm) is bent back and facing up. The figure is probably male and, given the caption, trying to swim but drowning in the attempt. He may be looking to the heavens for help, but is in despair.

component.illusobjdesc: The design is dominated by a stormy sky and sea, the former filled with clouds and the latter fraught with two large waves.

Near one wave crest we see a human arm raised vertically, fingers spread apart. This figure's head (just to the left of the arm) is bent back and facing up. The figure is probably male and, given the caption, trying to swim but drowning in the attempt. He may be looking to the heavens for help, but is in despair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is based on a traditional emblem of Age clipping the wings of Love. On the left sits a gowned old man wearing spectacles (an indication of limited vision). He has a long beard and probably long hair. His eyes are closed or looking down; he may be blind or almost blind. His mouth is open slightly. His legs, with prominent knees, are crossed at the ankles. His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand grasping the wing of the youthful figure to the right. His right arm is bent at the elbow; he holds in his right hand a pair of scissors with which he is about to cut the tip of the youth's right wing. This winged and youthful male figure, nude and striding energetically to the right, is a winged Cupid, cherub, or angel. His legs are spread apart, as though running to the right; he may be fleeing from the old man. The youth's hair is curly. His right arm is bent upward at the elbow, with the fingers of his raised right hand spread apart. His body faces to the right, but we see only the back of his head as he looks back to the sun rising or setting on the distant horizon. Lines of radiance emanate from the sun. A tree, its branches arching over both figures, grows up the left margin. The leaves of a tree or large plant fill the background above the old man. There may be grass on the slight hill or mound on which the two figures are placed.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left sits a gowned old man wearing spectacles (an indication of limited vision). He has a long beard and probably long hair. His eyes are closed or looking down; he may be blind are almost blind. His mouth is open slightly. His legs, with prominent knees, are crossed at the ankles. His left arm is raised horizontally, with the left hand grasping the wing of the youthful figure to the right. His right arm is bent at the elbow; he holds in his right hand a pair of scissors with which he is about to cut the tip of the youth's right wing.

A winged and youthful male figure, nude and striding energetically to the right, is a winged Cupid, cherub, or angel. His legs are spread apart, as though running to the right; he may be fleeing from the old man. The youth's hair is curly. His right arm is bent upward at the elbow, with the fingers of his raised right hand spread apart. A few lines indicate the youth's genitals. His body faces to the right, but we see only the back of his head as he looks back to the sun rising or setting on the distant horizon.
We see about half the sun rising or setting. Radiant beams of light emanate from it.

A tree, its branches arching over both figures, grows up the left margin. The leaves of a tree or large plant fill the background above the old man. There may be grass on the slight hill or mound on which the two figures are placed.

lg.l: Perceptive Organs closed their Objects close

illustration.illusobjdesc: Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated male figures, all apparently nude (with the possible exceptions of the figures lower left and right). The central figure, facing forward, is old and bearded with hair standing on end; the others are much younger. He, and the two figures next to him, appear to be sitting on a low stone step. There may be three small windows above them. The larger, older central figure has his legs drawn up; his knees are very prominent. His face suggests despair or worse. Immediately to the left, very close to the old man, is a young man with legs drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His knees are also prominent. His body faces forward, but his head is turned up and to the right; he may be looking at the face of the old man. Although we see only his right shoulder and upper arm, his right arm may be extended horizontally; he may be embracing the old man. On the right is another young male close to the old man. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, with prominent knees. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the left, with his face pressed against the body or left leg of the old man. This figure's hair seems to be long. Another youthful male sits in the right foreground. His legs are extended but slightly bent at the knees. Although probably nude, like his companions, lines just below his knees suggest that he might be wearing breeches. His left arm is at his side, with his left hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread apart. He faces left, with his head bent back and looking up; his mouth is slightly open. His hair is probably long. In the left foreground is the final youthful figure, seated and with legs extended. Though he may be nude, lines just below his knees suggest that he, too, may be wearing breeches. He faces to the right, with his head down. His right arm is at is side, with his right hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread. His hair is curly. Given the configuration of the males, the setting, and the compositional relationship to several drawings by Blake, this design would seem to be inspired by Dante's description of Count Ugolino and his sons in prison.

component.illusobjdesc: Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated figures. The central, older figure and the two younger figures next to him appear to be sitting on a low stone step. There might be three small windows above them.

Within a small room, probably a prison cell built of stone, we see five seated male figures, all apparently nude (with the possible exception of the figures lower left and right, who may wear breeches). Given the configuration of these figures, the setting, and the compositional relationship to several drawings by Blake, this design would seem to be inspired by Dante's description of Count Ugolino and his sons in prison. All appear to be dying in pain and despair.

The central seated figure, male and apparently nude, in this group of five faces forward. He is old and bearded with hair standing on end. He has his legs drawn up; his knees are very prominent. His face suggests despair or worse. He may be Ugolino.

A youthful male nude sits next to the old man in the center of the design. His hair is long and perhaps drawn into a bun. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles. His knees are prominent. His body faces forward, but his head is turned up and to the right; he may be looking at the face of the old man. Although we see only his right shoulder and upper arm, his right arm may be extended horizontally; he may be embracing the old man.

A youthful male nude sits next to the old man in the center of the design. His legs are drawn up and crossed at the ankles, with prominent knees. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the left, with his face pressed against the body or left leg of the old man. This figure's hair seems to be long.

A youthful male sits in the lower right corner of the cell. He is probably nude, but lines just below his knees suggest that he may be wearing breeches. His legs are extended but slightly bent at the knees. His left arm is at his side, with his left hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread apart. He faces left, with his head bent back and looking up; his mouth is slightly open. His hair is probably long.

A youthful male sits in the lower left corner of the cell. He is probably nude, but lines just below his knees suggest that he may be wearing breeches. He faces to the right, with his head down. His right arm is at is side, with his right hand on the ground (or, rather, on the floor), fingers spread. His hair is curly.

lg.l: 12Does thy God O Priest take such vengeance

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state for For the Sexes, with the head of the child immediately right of the woman turned toward the viewer. In the first state, the child's head is in right profile.

illustration.illusobjdesc: We see the corner of a featureless chamber or cell, perhaps with stone walls and a wooden floor. The only furniture is a bed (or possibly a bier), probably made of wood. A bodyvery probably deadlies supine and rigid on the bed, legs together and at least the right arm at his side. This gowned figure is very probably an old man, as indicated by his long beard. His face is hidden by another figure. At his feet, rising into the air at a 45 degree angle from lower right to upper left, is another gowned and bearded old man. We can see the supine figure's feet through the lower leg of the rising figure, and thus he is almost certainly the ghost or spirit of the dead man. His hair is long and he faces to the left. His right arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised horizontally across his body. The index finger of his right hand is extended and points to the right. His left arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised vertically. One finger of his left hand points upward. A radiant light surrounds his head and body, extending down to his lower legs. The effect is particularly prominent around his head and strongly suggests and halo. Beams of light radiate from his aura on the left. In the foreground on the left is a young man with curly hair. He squats or sits on his left leg, bent under his body; his right leg is extended to the right and bent slightly at the knee. He may be wearing tights, or at least a belt around his waist. His right arm is at his side, with the fingers of his right hand spread apart. His mouth is slightly open and he appears to be looking up and to the right in fear or surprise at the ghostly figure above and to the right. He may be the son of the dead man. Behind the bed and its corpse we see the head and upper body of a gowned woman wearing a scarf over her head. Her left arm is extended at 45 degrees. She also looks up and to the right at the ghost, perhaps with an expression of fear or surprise. She may be the wife or daughter of the dead man. Behind her and to the right are two small figures, probably children or grandchildren of the dead man. Of the child immediately to the right, we see only the face. The child faces toward the viewer. The child farthest to the right in this group is probably a male with curly hair. We see only his face and upper chest. He is probably looking up and to the right at the ghost.

component.illusobjdesc: We see the corner of a featureless chamber or cell, perhaps with stone walls and a wooden floor.
The only piece of furniture in the room is a bed or bier, probably made of wood.
The group of figures in the design may be a family--a dead father on the bed, his wife, and three children.

A body--very probably dead--lies supine and rigid on the bed, legs together and at least the right arm at his side. This gowned figure is very probably an old man, as indicated by his long beard. His face is hidden by another figure.

At the feet of the body on the bed or bier, rising into the air at a 45 degree angle from lower right to upper left, is another gowned and bearded old man. We can see the supine figure's feet through the lower leg of the rising figure, and thus the latter is almost certainly the ghost or spirit of the dead man. His hair is long and he faces to the left. His right arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised horizontally across his body. The index finger of his right hand is extended and points to the right. His left arm is bent at the elbow with the forearm raised vertically. One finger of his left hand points upward. A radiant light surrounds his head and body, extending down to his lower legs. The effect is particularly prominent around his head and strongly suggests and halo. Beams of light radiate from his aura on the left.

In the foreground on the left is a young man with curly hair. He squats or sits on his left leg, bent under his body; his right leg is extended to the right and bent slightly at the knee. He may be wearing tights, or at least a belt around his waist. His right arm is at his side, with the fingers of his right hand spread apart. His mouth is slightly open and he appears to be looking up and to the right in fear or surprise at the ghostly figure above and to the right. He may be the son of the dead man.

Behind the bed and its corpse we see the head and upper body of a gowned woman wearing a scarf over her head. Her left arm is raised at 45 degrees. She looks up and to the right at the ghost, perhaps with an expression of fear or surprise. She may be the wife or daughter of the dead man.

Behind the prominent female figure and to the right are two small figures, probably children or grandchildren of the dead man. Of the child closest to the woman, we see only the face. The child faces toward the viewer. The child farthest to the right in this group is probably a male with curly hair. We see only his face and upper chest. He is probably looking up and to the right at the ghost. Both children's mouths appear to be open.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A male traveler strides boldly to the right. He wears a coat, breeches, shoes, and a hat; he holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His right arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm raised horizontally. His hair would appear to be long. A long shadow extends from his left foot; another may form the dark triangle lower right. The ground beneath his feet may be covered with grass; leafy trees or large plants form the background. A few clouds fill the sky above.

component.illusobjdesc: A long shadow extends from the figure's left foot; another may form the dark triangle lower right.

A male traveler strides boldly to the right. He wears a coat, breeches, shoes, and a hat; he holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His right arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm raised horizontally. His hair would appear to be long.
The ground beneath the walking man's feet may be covered with grass; leafy trees or large plants form the background.
A few clouds fill the sky above the trees.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The entire image is filled with a door in a building, wall, or tomb. The posts and lintel of this structure are made of stone; the partly-opened door into the dark chamber is made of wood. Into this doorway steps an old man leaning on a single crutch under his left arm. He apparently holds the crutch with his left hand. His beard is long; his long hair streams out to the left, the direction in which he is facing, as though shaped by a wind blowing from right to left and into the tomb or chamber. His left foot is on tiptoe; his right foot and leg are not pictured beneath his long gown. Given the caption, the man is entering his tomb and thus dying.

component.illusobjdesc: The entire image is filled with a door in a building, wall, or tomb. The posts and lintel of this structure are made of stone; the partly-opened door into the dark chamber is made of wood.

An old man leaning on a single crutch under his left arm steps into a doorway. He apparently holds the crutch with his left hand. His beard is long; his long hair streams out to the left, the direction in which he is facing, as though shaped by a wind blowing from right to left and into the tomb or chamber. His left foot is on tiptoe; his right foot and leg are not pictured beneath his long gown. Given the caption, the man is entering his tomb and thus dying.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure of uncertain gender squats or sits, with legs drawn up and prominent knees, upon the earth. The figure, who faces forward, has a scarf or hood over the head. Arms at side, the figure holds a slender staff in the right hand. The left hand is on the ground. The figure appears to be looking, with open eyes, directly at the viewer. A worm lies on the ground, encircling the figure and reaching upward in a loop on the right side of the figure. Further to the lower right are two or three heads partly buried in the earth. These may be severed heads, or the heads of corpses whose bodies are buried in graves below the seated figure. The front-most figure, probably male and bearded, has his eyes closed. The dark background is filled with the leafless limbs, trunks, and roots of trees. There may also be a small plant, lower left, large stones (particularly on the left), and a cave behind and above the seated figure.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned figure of uncertain gender squats or sits, with legs drawn up and prominent knees, upon the earth. The figure, who faces forward, has a scarf or hood over the head. Arms at side, the figure holds a slender staff in the right hand. The left hand is on the ground. The figure appears to be looking, with open eyes, directly at the viewer.
A worm lies on the ground, encircling the seated figure and reaching upward in a loop on the right side of the figure.

In the lower right corner of the image are two or three heads partly buried in the earth. These may be severed heads, or the heads of corpses whose bodies are buried in graves below the seated figure. The front-most figure, probably male and bearded, has his eyes closed.
The dark background is filled with the leafless limbs, trunks, and roots of trees. There may be a small plant growing in the lower left corner of the image.
The background of the image may include large stones, particularly on the right, and a cave behind and above the seated figure.

lg.l: 16I have said to the Worm: Thou

illustration.illusobjdesc: Just left of the first letter of the first word of the heading ("The Keys" [line 1]), two standing or hovering figures embrace. Both are probably gowned. The figure on the left, perhaps female, may have one arm raised at 135 degrees. She faces right; her companion, presumably male, faces left. Between the words "The" and "Keys," a gowned and hovering figure has her or his arms raised vertically and holds a triangular object over her or his head.

component.illusobjdesc: Just left of the first letter of the first word of the heading ("The Keys" [line 1]), two standing or hovering figures embrace. Both are probably gowned. The figure on the left, perhaps female, may have one arm raised at 135 degrees. She faces right; her companion, presumably male, faces left.
Between the words "The" and "Keys" in the first line of the text, a gowned and hovering figure has her or his arms raised vertically and holds a triangular object over her or his head.

lg.l: Reminds thee of thy Mothers Grief
1 My Eternal Man set in Repose
The Female from his darkness rose
And She found me beneath a Tree
A Mandrake & in her Veil hid me
4 Naked in Air in Shame & Fear
5 Blind in Fire with shield & spear
In Doubt which is Self contradiction
Rational Truth Root of Evil & Good
Round me flew the Flaming Sword
Freezing her Veil the Mundane Shell
6 I rent the Veil where the Dead dwell
When weary Man enters his Cave

l.note: This number was added, probably by Blake, to this impression in pen and ink.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several forms decorate the left margin of the text. A figure, probably winged and facing right, hovers left of line 15. Another hovering figure proceeds line 17. Line 21 is introduced by another hovering figure, probably facing forward and arms raised at approximately 135 degrees. Twisting vines grow left of lines 25 and 27-29.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably winged and facing right, hovers left of line 15 of the text.
A hovering figure proceeds line 17 of the text.
Line 21 of the text is introduced by a hovering figure, probably facing forward and arms raised at approximately 135 degrees.
Twisting vines grow left of lines 25 and 27-29 of the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several images decorate the right margin of the text. Those following lines 2 and 3 may simply be leaves or flowers. Right of line 7 are two hovering figures, apparently facing each other. The figure on the left has her or his arms raised at 45 degrees; the figure on the right has his or her arms raised horizontally. Another hovering figure, arms raised at 45 degrees, follows lines 11-12. Two hovering figures follow line 15. A larger hovering figure, probably gowned, follows line 17. This figure, probably female and facing forward, has one arm raised horizontally and the other raised vertically. An embracing and hovering couple follows lines 19-20. Behind them are slight indications of steps and a building and doorway (possibly one of the "Dungeons" referenced in line 18). Vines spiral in loops right of lines 22-23, 26-28, and 29. A wavy line, perhaps a vine, appears below "over the Web" in the last line of text.

component.illusobjdesc: The slight forms following lines 2 and 3 of the text may be leaves or flowers.

Right of line 7 are two hovering figures, apparently facing each other. The figure on the left has her or his arms raised at 45 degrees; the figure on the right has his or her arms raised horizontally.
Another hovering figure, arms raised at 45 degrees, follows lines 11-12 of the text. The figure's legs are bent.
Two hovering figures follow line 15 of the text. The figure on the far right seems twisted with legs bent.
A hovering figure, probably gowned, follows line 17 of the text. This figure, probably female and facing forward, has one arm raised horizontally and the other raised vertically.
An embracing and hovering couple follows lines 19-20 of the text.
Behind the figures following lines 19-20 of the text are slight indications of steps and doorway of a building (possibly one of the "Dungeons" referenced in line 18).
Vines spiral in loops right of lines 22-23, 26-28, and 29 of the text. A wavy line, perhaps a vine, appears below "over the Web" in the last line of text.

lg.l: He meets his Saviour in the Grave
Some find a Female Garment there
And some a Male. woven with care
Should grow a devouring, Winding sheet
7 One Dies! Alas! the Living & Dead
One is slain & One is fled
My Son! my Son! thou treatest me
But as I have instructed thee
9 On the shadows of the Moon
11 Holy & cold I clipd the Wings
12 And in depths of my Dungeons
13 But when once I did descry
The Immortal Man that cannot Die
14 Thro evening shades I haste away
To close the Labours of my Day
15 The Door of Death I open found
And the Worm Weaving in the Ground
16 Thou'rt my Mother from the Womb
Wife. Sister. Daughter to the Tomb
Weaving to Dreams the Sexual strife
And weeping over the Web of Life

l.note: This number was added, probably by Blake, to this impression in pen and ink.

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state for For the Sexes. In the first state, the figure's body and wings are engraved principally in outline and lack the dark hatching strokes of the second state.

illustration.illusobjdesc: We see from behind a bat-winged figure, almost certainly male, flying or hovering in the air. He faces away from the viewer and is dark-skinned, nude and bald. His arms are apparently raised horizontally, for we can see his hands, fingers spread apart, extending beyond each wing. His right leg is drawn up behind him, his left bent slightly at the knee but extended to the left. At least ten stars and two circles decorate his wings. The circle on the left is probably the moon (note the slight indications of a crescent within the circle); the circle on the right may be the sun (note the radiance just outside the circumference). This figure is no doubt Satan, "The Accuser who is The God of This World," named in the first three lines of the text on this plate. He can also be associated with Blake's concept of the spectre. Lying supine on the ground beneath the winged figure is the "lost Traveller" named in line 10. He is a muscular male and would appear to be nude; his hair is long. His eyes are closed, for he is very probably asleep and dreaming (see line 10). His neck is twisted so that he faces forward. His head may be resting on a stone or mound of earth and his legs may be crossed at the ankles. His right arm is at his side, with his right arm holding (or at least resting on) a staff or walking-stick. The background landscape on the right is filled with a hill (see the last word on this plate) and radiant beams of light (a sunrise or sunset?) rising above the hill. On the left, the beams of light may be issuing from the background horizon, but they also form a halo-like radiance above the traveler's head.

component.illusobjdesc: We see from behind a bat-winged figure, almost certainly male, flying or hovering in the air. He faces away from the viewer and is dark-skinned, nude and bald. His arms are apparently raised horizontally, for we can see his hands, fingers spread apart, extending beyond each wing. His right leg is drawn up behind him, his left bent slightly at the knee but extended to the left. At least ten stars and two circles decorate his wings. The circle on the left is probably the moon (note the slight indications of a crescent within the circle); the circle on the right may be the sun (note the radiance just outside the circumference). This figure is no doubt Satan, "The Accuser who is The God of This World," named in the first three lines of the text on this plate. He can also be associated with Blake's concept of the spectre.

Lying supine on the ground beneath the winged figure is the "lost Traveller" named in line 10. He is a muscular male and would appear to be nude; his hair is long. His eyes are closed, for he is very probably asleep and dreaming (see line 10). His neck is twisted so that he faces forward. His head may be resting on a stone and his legs may be crossed at the ankles. His right arm is at his side, with his right arm holding (or at least resting on) a staff or walking- stick.
The sleeping figure's head may be resting on a stone or mound of earth.
The background on the right is dominated by a hill (see the final word of line 10) and, just above it, radiance and beams of light that may indicate a sunrise or sunset.
On the left and just above the sleeping figure's head, the beams of light may indicate a sunrise or sunset, but they also form a halo-like radiance above the sleeping figure's head.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A snake with open mouth and a prominent tongue faces to the right between the second and third lines of text. The snake's body forms a spiral and his head bears a small crest. At least the first nine loops, reading back from the snake's head, are numbered consecutively 1-9.

component.illusobjdesc: A snake with open mouth and a prominent tongue faces to the right between the second and third lines of text. The snake's body forms a spiral. His head bears a small crest. At least the first nine loops, reading back from the snake's head, are numbered consecutively 1-9.
At least the first nine loops of the snake's body are numbered 1-9, reading back from his head.

lg.l: Truly My Satan thou art but a Dunce
And dost not know the Garment from the Man
Every Harlot was a Virgin once
Nor canst thou ever change Kate into Nan
Tho thou art Worshipd by the Names Divine
Of Jesus & Jehovah; thou art still
The Son of Morn in weary Nights decline
The lost Travellers Dream under the Hill

l.note: This number was added, probably by Blake, to this impression in pen and ink.
